p: Over the last two decades, there were significant advances in understanding MM disease biology and in development of several new drugs that allowed a paradigm shift from a palliative intent towards the active management of the disease aiming to prolong event-free survival (EFS) and overall survival (OS) [ 1]. Nowadays, induction followed by autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) after high-dose melphalan conditioning continues the standard treatment for MM patients under the age of 65 years [ 1, 5– 7]. Some studies suggest that age at the time of transplant does not have prognostic significance on outcome after ASCT [ 8, 9], but its safety and efficacy remain uncertain for patients over that age [ 9– 16].
